questions.body: Regarding genetic transmission of bipolar disorder, has any specific gene/mutation been identified?

snippets.text: single nucleotide polymorphism rs13166360, causing a substitution of valine (Val) 147 to leucine (Leu) in the adenylyl cyclase 2 (ADCY2), has previously been associated with bipolar disorder
CNVs in RNF216 and postsynaptic membrane-related genes confer a risk of BD

Affective disorders and, in particular, bipolar affective disorder (BPAD) have been examined in many molecular genetic studies which have covered a large part of the genome. Specific hypotheses such as mutations have also been studied. Most recent studies indicate that several chromosomal regions may be involved in the aetiology of BPAD. These include genes on chromosomes 18, 21, 4, 5, 11 and X.
MIR218 polygenic risk score is associated with cognitive function and neurochemical metabolites among patients with depressed bipolar disorders.

Linkage studies have defined several BPD susceptibility loci. The findings to date suggested the candidate regions on 4p16, 12q23-24, 18p11, 18q22, 21q22, Xq24-27 for BPD, although no genes has yet been definitively identified. There are also many reports on the analyses of candidate genes, using association studies. But none of gene polymorphisms have been established as firm disease alleles with sufficient replications.

The association between manic-depressive illness and IMPA2 variants supports several reports on the linkage of bipolar disorder to chromosome 18p11.2, and sustains the possible role of IMPA2 as a susceptibility gene in bipolar disorder.

The serotonin transporter (HTT) is an important candidate gene for the genetic transmission of bipolar disorder. It is the site of action of many antidepressants, and plays a key role in the regulation of serotonin neurotransmission.
The serotonin transporter (HTT) is an important candidate gene for the genetic transmission of bipolar disorder.

questions.body: How does hypoxia influence the cell states of glioblastoma multiforme (GBM)?

snippets.text: Glioblastoma (GBM) is the most common primary malignant cancer of the central nervous system. Insufficient oxygenation (hypoxia) has been linked to GBM invasion and aggression, leading to poor patient outcomes. Hypoxia induces gene expression for cellular adaptations. However, GBM is characterized by high intertumoral (molecular subtypes) and intratumoral heterogeneity (cell states), and it is not well understood to what extent hypoxia triggers patient-specific gene responses and cellular diversity in GBM.

Hypoxia gene signature to single cell RNA-seq datasets of glioma patients, which showed that hypoxic cells displayed a shift towards mesenchymal-like (MES) and astrocyte-like (AC) states. Interestingly, in response to hypoxia, tumor cells in IDH-mutant gliomas displayed a strong shift to the AC state, whereas tumor cells in IDH-wildtype gliomas mainly shifted to the MES state. This distinct hypoxia response of IDH-mutant gliomas may contribute to its more favorable prognosis. Our transcriptomic studies provide a basis for future approaches to better understand the diversity of hypoxic niches in gliomas.

We find three prominent modes of organization. First, gliomas are composed of small local environments, each typically enriched with one major cellular state. Second, specific pairs of states preferentially reside in proximity across multiple scales. This pairing of states is consistent across tumors. Third, these pairwise interactions collectively define a global architecture composed of five layers. Hypoxia appears to drive the layers, as it is associated with a long-range organization that includes all cancer cell states.
In summary, we provide a conceptual framework for the organization of cellular states in glioma, highlighting hypoxia as a long-range tissue organizer.

We further applied the Shared GBM Hypoxia gene signature to single cell RNA-seq datasets of glioma patients, which showed that hypoxic cells displayed a shift towards mesenchymal-like (MES) and astrocyte-like (AC) states. Interestingly, in response to hypoxia, tumor cells in IDH-mutant gliomas displayed a strong shift to the AC state, whereas tumor cells in IDH-wildtype gliomas mainly shifted to the MES state. This distinct hypoxia response of IDH-mutant gliomas may contribute to its more favorable prognosis.
Hypoxia Contributes to Poor Prognosis in Primary IDH-wt GBM by Inducing Tumor Cells MES-Like Transformation Trend and Inhibiting Immune Cells Activity.
In addition, there are links between hypoxia and the phenomenon of mesenchymal transition in gliomas.

The exposure of non-mesenchymal SNB75 and U87 cells to hypoxia induced a strong change in cell morphology that was accompanied by enhanced invasive capacity and the acquisition of mesenchymal marker expression. Further analyses showed the induction of HIF1α and HIF2α by hypoxia and exposure to digoxin, a cardiac glycoside known to inhibit HIF1/2 expression, was able to prevent hypoxia-induced mesenchymal transition. ShRNA-mediated knockdown of HIF1α, and not HIF2α, prevented this transition, as well as the knockdown of the EMT transcription factor ZEB1. We provide further evidence for a hypoxia-induced mesenchymal shift in GBM primary material by showing co-localization of GLUT1, ZEB1 and the mesenchymal marker YKL40 in hypoxic regions of the tumor.

We further applied the Shared GBM Hypoxia gene signature to single cell RNA-seq datasets of glioma patients, which showed that hypoxic cells displayed a shift towards mesenchymal-like (MES) and astrocyte-like (AC) states.

ideal_answer: Glioblastoma multiforme (GBM) is the most common primary malignant cancer of the central nervous system. Insufficient oxygenation (hypoxia) has been linked to GBM invasion and aggression, leading to poor patient outcomes. However, GBM is characterized by high intratumoral heterogeneity (cell states), and it is not well understood to what extent hypoxia triggers patient-specific gene responses and cellular diversity in GBM. A study of hypoxia gene signature in scRNA-seq data of glioma patients showed that hypoxic cells displayed a shift towards mesenchymal-like (MES) and astrocyte-like (AC) states. Interestingly, in response to hypoxia, tumor cells in IDH-mutant gliomas displayed a strong shift to the AC state, whereas tumor cells in IDH-wildtype gliomas mainly shifted to the MES state. This distinct hypoxia response of IDH-mutant gliomas may contribute to its more favorable prognosis. In addition, hypoxia has also been shown - using spatial transcriptomics - to act as a tissue cell state organizer both in small local environments and in long-range interactions.

In response to hypoxia, tumor cells in IDH-mutant gliomas display a strong shift to the AC state, whereas tumor cells in IDH-wildtype gliomas mainly shift to the MES state. Hypoxia, or low oxygen levels, plays a significant role in driving glioblastoma multiforme (GBM) progression and therapeutic resistance. Hypoxia induces the expression of hypoxia-inducible factors (HIFs) which regulate genes involved in cellular adaptations like increased glycolysis, angiogenesis, autophagy, and invasion. Hypoxia promotes a shift towards more aggressive mesenchymal-like and astrocyte-like cell states in GBM. Interestingly, in IDH-mutant gliomas, hypoxia drives a stronger shift towards the astrocyte-like state, while in IDH-wildtype gliomas, it promotes a mesenchymal-like state. This distinct hypoxia response may contribute to the more favorable prognosis of IDH-mutant gliomas. Hypoxia also maintains glioblastoma stem cells which are resistant to therapy and can initiate tumor recurrence.

Hypoxia significantly influences glioblastoma multiforme (GBM) cell states, driving them towards more aggressive, stem-like phenotypes. This is characterized by shifts towards Mesenchymal-like (MES) and Astrocyte-like (AC) states, with IDH-mutant gliomas predominantly adopting the AC state. Key changes include upregulation of stemness factors (SOX2, Oct4), dysregulation of microRNAs and survival genes, and alterations in metabolism, angiogenesis, and autophagy. Notably, a phase transition occurs in the mTORC1 signaling network near 1.5% oxygen partial pressure. These adaptations contribute to increased self-renewal, drug resistance, and patient-specific responses, highlighting the complexity of hypoxia's impact on GBM.

Reoxygenation triggers a shift towards a more differentiated state. Understanding hypoxia's impact on GBM cell states is crucial for developing effective treatment strategies.

questions.body: What's the increase in CORE profiles in JASPAR 2024 compared to the previous version?

snippets.text: JASPAR (https://jaspar.elixir.no/) is a widely-used open-access database presenting manually curated high-quality and non-redundant DNA-binding profiles for transcription factors (TFs) across taxa. In this 10th release and 20th-anniversary update, the CORE collection has expanded with 329 new profiles. We updated three existing profiles and provided orthogonal support for 72 profiles from the previous release's UNVALIDATED collection. Altogether, the JASPAR 2024 update provides a 20% increase in CORE profiles from the previous release.

The most serious complication associated with metformin is lactic acidosis which has an incidence of about 0.03 cases per 1000 patients years of treatment and a mortality risk of about 0.015 per 1000 patient-years. Most cases occur in patients who are wrongly prescribed the drug, particularly patients with impaired renal function (e.g. serum creatinine level > 130 micromol/L or > 1.5 g/L). Other major contraindications include congestive heart failure, hypoxic states and advanced liver disease. Serious adverse events with metformin are predictable rather than spontaneous and are potentially preventable if the prescribing guidelines are respected. Gastrointestinal adverse effects, notably diarrhoea, occur in less than 20% of patients and remit when the dosage is reduced. The life-threatening risks associated with metformin are rare and could mostly be avoided by strict adherence to the prescribing guidelines.

ideal_answer: The most common adverse effects of metformin are gastrointestinal side effects such as nausea, diarrhea, anorexia, and metallic taste. Metformin can also cause vitamin B12 malabsorption. The most serious but rare adverse effect is lactic acidosis, which can occur if metformin accumulates in patients with contraindications to its use, such as renal impairment.

Metformin is generally well-tolerated, but it can cause some adverse effects. The most common side effects include gastrointestinal issues such as nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal pain, and loss of appetite. Long-term use of metformin can lead to vitamin B12 deficiency, which may result in anemia or neuropathy. A rare but serious side effect is lactic acidosis, a condition characterized by the buildup of lactic acid in the blood, which can be life-threatening. Patients with kidney impairment, liver disease, or heart failure are at higher risk for lactic acidosis. Other potential side effects include skin reactions, taste disturbances, and hypoglycemia, especially when used in combination with other antidiabetic medications.

Metformin most commonly causes gastrointestinal adverse effects such as nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal pain, anorexia, and heartburn. It is also associated with a decrease in vitamin B12 absorption, with deficiency rates around 18.6%. Rarely, abnormalities in blood counts and skin reactions have been reported. Although these digestive symptoms are frequent, lactic acidosis, while rare, is particularly dangerous, with a mortality rate ranging from 50 to 80%. This serious complication is more likely in patients with cardiovascular, pulmonary, renal, or liver failure. Other less common adverse events include hypoglycemia, taste alterations, epigastric cramps, and bloating. Overall, while metformin is generally safe and effective for managing diabetes, careful monitoring is important, especially in patients with predisposition to serious complications.

Metformin is a widely used medication for type 2 diabetes, known primarily for its ability to lower blood sugar levels. However, it can also cause several adverse effects:

1. **Gastrointestinal Issues:** Common side effects include nausea, diarrhea, and stomach discomfort, which are usually mild but can be bothersome.

2. **Lactic Acidosis:** A rare but serious condition where lactate builds up in the body, leading to blood acidity. This risk is higher in individuals with kidney problems, as the kidneys play a key role in clearing lactate.

3. **Vitamin B12 Levels:** Long-term use can lead to lower vitamin B12 levels, potentially causing anemia or neurological symptoms like numbness and tingling.

4. **Metabolic Effects:** Metformin may influence lipid metabolism, affecting cholesterol levels, and could cause weight changes, though it is generally weight-neutral.

5. **Hypoglycemia Risk:** While metformin alone doesn't typically cause hypoglycemia, the risk increases when combined with other blood sugar-lowering medications.

6. **Liver Function:** Mainly metabolized in the liver, patients with pre-existing liver conditions might have an increased risk of side effects, though it's generally safe for mild liver issues with monitoring.

7. **Allergic Reactions:** Some individuals may experience rashes or itching, necessitating immediate medical attention and discontinuation of the drug.

8. **Kidney Function Monitoring:** Essential before starting metformin to assess suitability, especially in those with renal impairment.

9. **Long-term Considerations:** Regular monitoring of vitamin B12 levels and kidney function is crucial for long-term users, particularly on higher doses.

Understanding these risks helps in managing the use of metformin effectively, ensuring patient safety and optimal outcomes.

**Exact Answer:**

Gastrointestinal upset; lactic acidosis; vitamin B12 deficiency; metabolic effects (lipid metabolism); allergic reactions.

Single-cell data has made it possible to characterize cells from patients into four cell states, namely: (i) neural progenitor-like (NPC-like), (ii) oligodendrocyte progenitor-like (OPC-like), (iii) astrocyte-like (AC-like), and (iv) mesenchymal-like (MES-like), influencing both drug response and survival outcomes.

These distinct cellular states exhibit plasticity and can transition between states, contributing to the heterogeneity and therapeutic resistance of GBM.

Glioblastoma multiforme (GBM) is characterized by heterogeneity at the cellular and molecular levels. Cells from patients can be categorized into four cell states: neural progenitor-like (NPC-like), oligodendrocyte progenitor-like (OPC-like), astrocyte-like (AC-like), and mesenchymal-like (MES-like). The Cancer Genome Atlas Consortium has also classified GBM into subtypes such as classic, mesenchymal, proneural, and neural GBM. Aberrations and gene expression of EGFR, NF1, and PDGFRA/IDH1 each define the Classical, Mesenchymal, and Proneural subtypes, respectively.

The main cell states of glioblastoma multiforme (GBM) are: (1) Neural Progenitor-like (NPC-like), resembling neural stem cells; (2) Oligodendrocyte Progenitor-like (OPC-like), sharing traits with oligodendrocyte progenitor cells; (3) Astrocyte-like (AC-like), similar to astrocytes; and (4) Mesenchymal-like (MES-like), associated with mesenchymal transition and therapy resistance. Identified through multiomic analysis, network modeling, and patient data, these states influence treatment outcomes and offer potential drug targets by targeting specific proteins and pathways. Understanding these cell states is crucial for addressing GBM's intratumor heterogeneity and epigenetic plasticity.

Glioblastoma multiforme (GBM) is characterized by significant intratumor heterogeneity, which can be categorized into four main cellular states based on single cell RNA sequencing and bulk RNA sequencing data. These cell states are: 1. Neural Progenitor like (NPC like): Resemble neural progenitors and may contribute to tumor growth and invasion. 2. Oligodendrocyte Progenitor like (OPC like): Share similarities with oligodendrocyte progenitors and are associated with proliferative activity. 3. Astrocyte like (AC like): Resemble reactive astrocytes and may play a role in the tumor microenvironment. 4. Mesenchymal like (MES like): Exhibit mesenchymal features, including high invasiveness and resistance to therapy. These cell states highlight the functional heterogeneity within GBM tumors and provide insights into potential therapeutic targets.

These cell states reflect the tumor's cellular heterogeneity, influencing its behavior, treatment outcomes, and patient prognosis. 2. **Oligodendrocyte progenitor-like (OPC-like)**: Cells resembling oligodendrocyte progenitors, which are involved in myelination and repair processes.
3. **Astrocyte-like (AC-like)**: Cells resembling mature astrocytes, often associated with reactive gliosis and tumor progression.
4. **Mesenchymal-like (MES-like)**: Cells exhibiting mesenchymal features, including increased invasiveness and resistance to therapy.

Dengue infection is primarily transmitted to humans through the bite of infected female mosquitoes, particularly of the species Aedes aegypti and, to a lesser extent, Aedes albopictus. These mosquitoes are prevalent in tropical and subtropical regions and are most active during the early morning and late afternoon. Effective control of these mosquito populations is crucial in preventing the spread of dengue.

The vector responsible for transmitting the dengue virus is primarily the Aedes aegypti mosquito, with Aedes albopictus also playing a significant role. These mosquitoes are known as yellow fever and Asian tiger mosquitoes, respectively. They breed in stagnant water sources near human habitats and bite during daylight hours, facilitating disease transmission. When an infected mosquito bites a person, it transmits the dengue virus, perpetuating the infection cycle and contributing to outbreaks in regions where these species are prevalent.

The primary vectors of dengue infection are the mosquitoes Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus, with Aedes aegypti being the most significant. These mosquitoes transmit the dengue virus, a single-stranded RNA virus of the Flaviviridae family, through their bites. While Aedes albopictus is also a vector, it is generally less competent and associated with milder epidemics compared to Aedes aegypti.

Studies have shown that Aedes aegypti mosquitoes are the principal vectors of dengue, a mosquito-borne flavivirus. However, during several outbreaks of chikungunya and dengue along Mediterranean coasts in recent decades, Aedes albopictus was identified as the vector involved in these events. This indicates that while Aedes aegypti is primarily responsible for transmitting dengue, Aedes albopictus can also play a significant role in specific outbreaks.

snippets.text: We found that recurrent GBMs are characterized by a shift to a mesenchymal phenotype. We show that the mesenchymal state is mediated by activator protein 1.

Glioblastomas (GBM) are aggressive brain tumors that inevitably recur despite surgical resection, chemotherapy, and radiation. The degree to which recurrent GBM retains its initial immunophenotype is incompletely understood.

Recurrent tumors showed decreased staining for CD34 suggesting lower vessel density. A subset of tumors showed increased staining for markers associated with the mesenchymal gene expression pattern, including CD44, phosphorylated STAT3, and YKL40.

ideal_answer: Glioblastomas (GBM) are aggressive brain tumors that inevitably recur despite surgical resection, chemotherapy, and radiation. These recurrent GBMs are characterized by a shift to a mesenchymal phenotype, which is mediated by activator protein 1, and are characterized by a more aggressive clinical behavior.

Several studies have found that recurrent glioblastomas exhibit a shift towards a more mesenchymal cell state compared to the primary tumors. This mesenchymal shift is characterized by increased expression of extracellular matrix and mesenchyme-related genes, and is associated with a more aggressive and therapy-resistant phenotype. The mesenchymal state appears to be mediated by transcription factors like MAFK, NFATC4, and activator protein 1 (AP-1) members. Additionally, recurrent tumors show altered interactions with non-neoplastic cells like reactive astrocytes, macrophages, and T cells in the tumor microenvironment.

Yes, there is a shift in cell states of glioblastoma during recurrence, primarily towards a mesenchymal phenotype mediated by activator protein 1. This shift, also characterized by the emergence of a VC-Resist cell state, leads to increased therapy resistance and enhanced tumor infiltration. Supported by single-cell analyses, functional assays, and animal studies, understanding this shift is crucial for developing targeted therapies. The transition allows glioblastoma cells to evade treatment and infiltrate surrounding brain tissue, highlighting the need for therapies addressing these adaptive changes.

Yes, a shift in cell states of glioblastoma during recurrence is observed, characterized by a transition to a mesenchymal phenotype, often mediated by activator protein 1. This shift is associated with increased resistance to chemoradiation, vessel co-option, and specific molecular changes, including DNA methylation subclass transitions. The emergence of a VC-Resist cell state during recurrence further contributes to treatment resistance, highlighting the dynamic and adaptive nature of glioblastoma cell states in response to therapy.

These parasites are transmitted to humans through the bite of infected tsetse flies (*Glossina* species). African animal trypanosomiasis (AAT), which affects livestock, is caused by other *Trypanosoma* species such as *T. congolense*, *T. vivax*, and *T. simiae*. 2. **Trypanosoma brucei rhodesiense**: This subspecies is responsible for the Rhodesian form, found in East and Southern Africa. It causes an acute infection with more rapid progression of symptoms.

These parasites are transmitted through the bite of infected tsetse flies (*Glossina* species), which serve as the vector for the disease. Once introduced into the human bloodstream, the parasites can spread throughout the body and eventually cross the blood-brain barrier, leading to conditions such as sleeping sickness. The disease is thus a significant public health issue in regions where these vectors are present.

questions.body: Describe Variant Ranker

snippets.text: Variant Ranker: a web-tool to rank genomic data according to functional significance.

We describe Variant Ranker, a user-friendly simple web-based tool for ranking, filtering and annotation of coding and non-coding variants. Variant Ranker facilitates the identification of causal variants based on novelty, effect and annotation information. The algorithm implements and aggregates multiple prediction algorithm scores, conservation scores, allelic frequencies, clinical information and additional open-source annotations using accessible databases via ANNOVAR.

Variant Ranker allows researchers to rank identified variants and determine the most confident variants for experimental validation.RESULTS: We describe Variant Ranker, a user-friendly simple web-based tool for ranking, filtering and annotation of coding and non-coding variants.

Our results indicate that Variant Ranker exhibits excellent performance by correctly identifying and ranking the candidate genes CONCLUSIONS: Variant Ranker is a freely available web server on http://paschou-lab.mbg.duth.gr/Software.html .
Variant Ranker facilitates the identification of causal variants based on novelty, effect and annotation information.

Variant Ranker is a web-tool that allows researchers to rank and prioritize identified genetic variants based on their functional significance. It helps analyze and interpret the large volume of genomic data generated by high-throughput sequencing techniques. By scoring and ranking variants based on annotations, Variant Ranker enables researchers to determine the most confident or potentially pathogenic variants for further experimental validation or clinical analysis.

Variant Ranker is a tool or method used to prioritize genetic variants based on their potential functional relevance. By leveraging publicly available databases, it characterizes loci in a functional context to identify and rank variants that may be significant for further study or clinical consideration. This process helps researchers focus on variants that are more likely to have an impact on disease or biological processes.

Variant Ranker is a user-friendly, web-based tool that ranks genomic variants (coding and non-coding) by their functional significance. It aggregates multiple data sources, including prediction scores, conservation scores, allelic frequencies, clinical information, and open-source annotations via ANNOVAR. Users can customize weights and apply different inheritance models. Key features include genotype filtering, customizable filtering, and downstream functional enrichment analysis through network visualization, aiding in identifying gene clusters related to specific ontology categories. Successfully demonstrated with real and synthetic datasets, Variant Ranker is freely available at http://paschou-lab.mbg.duth.gr/Software.html to facilitate the identification of causal variants.

Variant Ranker is a tool designed to help researchers rank identified genetic variants, enabling them to determine the most confident variants suitable for experimental validation. It was used to prioritize variants, leading to the validation of five rare variants in specific genes through Sanger sequencing, all of which were predicted to be deleterious, demonstrating its effectiveness in identifying significant variants.

Variant Ranker is a computational tool or software designed to prioritize and rank genetic variants based on their potential impact or relevance to a particular disease or phenotype. It typically integrates various types of data, such as genetic, functional, and clinical information, to assess the significance of each variant. The tool may use algorithms to evaluate factors like the predicted effect of a variant on protein function, its frequency in the population, and its association with known disease pathways. By doing so, Variant Ranker helps researchers and clinicians identify the most promising variants for further study or for consideration in diagnostic or therapeutic contexts.

It is applicable in various contexts, such as identifying causal variants in diseases like Tourette Syndrome, refining variant classification in functional assays, and improving classification accuracy in hematological malignancies through machine learning applied to RNA-sequencing data.

Variant Ranker is a user-friendly, web-based tool designed for ranking, filtering, and annotating both coding and non-coding genetic variants. The algorithm aggregates multiple prediction algorithm scores, conservation scores, allelic frequencies, clinical information, and open-source annotations using accessible databases via ANNOVAR. This can result in an overgrowth of pathogenic organisms and promote selection for antibiotic-resistant microorganisms.

ideal_answer: The use of statins can have adverse effects in a wide range of systems and cause development of type 2 diabetes mellitus, muscular symptoms, liver toxicity, kidney diseases, cataracts, hemorrhagic strokes, and psychiatric disease.

The most common adverse effects of statins include myopathy (muscle weakness, pain, and elevated creatine kinase levels), rhabdomyolysis (severe muscle breakdown), liver enzyme elevations, and an increased risk of developing type 2 diabetes. Less common side effects include peripheral neuropathy, cognitive impairment, autoimmune disorders, and cataracts. However, the benefits of statins in reducing cardiovascular events generally outweigh the risks of these adverse effects.

Statins have common adverse effects including myopathy (muscle pain to rhabdomyolysis), reversible liver enzyme elevation, and a slightly increased risk of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus, particularly in those with metabolic syndrome. Less common effects include drug-induced liver injury, peripheral neuropathy, and impaired myocardial contractility. Notably, the elderly are at higher risk. Most effects are reversible upon discontinuation. Despite these risks, the cardiovascular benefits of statins outweigh the non-cardiovascular harms, with no proven links to cancer or cognitive decline, and possible benefits in dementia prevention.

Statins are a class of drugs commonly used to lower cholesterol levels in the blood, which can help prevent cardiovascular diseases. However, they can have several adverse effects. Common side effects include muscle pain, fatigue, and digestive problems such as nausea, diarrhea, or constipation. Some individuals may experience more serious side effects, such as liver damage, which can be monitored through liver function tests. Statins can also increase blood sugar levels, potentially leading to type 2 diabetes in some patients. Rarely, statins can cause a severe muscle condition called rhabdomyolysis, which can lead to kidney damage. Other potential side effects include memory loss or confusion, although these are less common. It's important for patients to discuss any side effects with their healthcare provider to weigh the benefits and risks of continuing statin therapy.

Statin therapy, while generally safe and effective for managing cholesterol levels, is associated with several adverse effects. The most common side effect is myalgia, which occurs in 1-10% of patients. Statins can also cause myopathy, a more serious condition characterized by muscle damage. Additionally, long-term use has been linked to adverse renal effects, cognitive loss, neuropathy, pancreatic and hepatic dysfunction, and sexual dysfunction. Statins are also known to increase the risk of diabetes mellitus and can elevate hepatic transaminase levels, indicating potential liver dysfunction. These side effects highlight the need for careful monitoring and management when prescribing statins.

Statins are widely used medications to lower LDL cholesterol levels, but they can cause several adverse effects:

1. **Muscular Side Effects**: The most common side effects include myalgia (muscle pain), muscle weakness, and rarely, rhabdomyolysis (severe muscle breakdown). These effects are dose-dependent and may occur more frequently with higher doses.

2. **Liver Injury**: Statins can cause mild elevations in liver enzymes, though severe liver injury is rare.

3. **Sexual Dysfunction**: Some patients report loss of libido, erectile dysfunction, or testicular pain, which often resolve upon discontinuation of statins.

4. **Gastrointestinal Issues**: Nausea, diarrhea, and abdominal discomfort are less common but can occur.

5. **Neurocognitive Symptoms**: Rarely, statins may be associated with memory loss or confusion, though this is typically reversible.

6. **Other Effects**: Statins may also cause fatigue, headache, and, in rare cases, allergic reactions or skin rashes.

While many side effects are mild and transient, patients should inform their healthcare provider if they experience unusual symptoms. In most cases, discontinuing statins leads to resolution of adverse effects.

Statins, widely used for lowering cholesterol, have a range of adverse effects. Common adverse effects include muscle pain (myalgia), headache, abdominal pain, asthenia, nausea, liver enzyme abnormalities, nasopharyngitis, upper respiratory tract infection, arthralgia, diarrhea, back pain, influenza, pain in extremity, and fatigue. Serious adverse effects involve rhabdomyolysis with myoglobinuria, which can lead to acute renal failure, and myopathy, including myositis. Postmarketing reports have noted arthralgia, hepatic failure, hepatitis, jaundice, thrombocytopenia, depression, sleep disorders, peripheral neuropathy, interstitial lung disease, gynecomastia, and cognitive impairment. Additional findings from literature highlight rare but significant risks such as myopathy and rhabdomyolysis, asymptomatic elevation in hepatic transaminase levels, low risk of serious liver injury, proteinuria and hematuria at higher doses of rosuvastatin, new onset of type 2 diabetes, statin-associated muscle symptoms (SAMS) and myotoxicity, rare neurocognitive effects, mitochondrial dysfunction, epigenetic modifications, and a very rare cancer risk. While statins are generally safe and effective, the incidence and severity of these effects can vary based on the specific statin used, dosage, and presence of drug interactions.

The adverse effects of statins, known as Statin-Associated Symptoms (SAS), are multifaceted and rare in clinical trials, yet potentially impactful. They include: Development of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus, Muscular Symptoms (e.g., muscle pain, weakness, rare rhabdomyolysis), Liver Toxicity (mostly elevated liver enzymes), Kidney Diseases, Cataracts, Hemorrhagic Strokes, and Psychiatric Complications. These effects, though uncommon, may necessitate dose adjustments or therapy discontinuation, highlighting the need for cautious prescribing and monitoring across various body systems (metabolic, musculoskeletal, hepatic, renal, ocular, cerebrovascular, and neuropsychiatric).

Statins are a class of drugs commonly prescribed to lower cholesterol levels and reduce the risk of cardiovascular diseases. While they offer significant benefits, they also come with potential adverse effects that should be carefully considered:

1. **Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus**: There is a slight increase in the risk of developing type 2 diabetes among statin users, though this risk is generally small compared to the protective effects on cardiovascular health.

2. **Muscular Symptoms**: Statins can cause muscle-related side effects such as myalgia (muscle pain) and myopathy (inflammation of the muscles). Rarely, they may lead to rhabdomyolysis, a severe condition involving rapid breakdown of muscle tissue.

3. **Liver Toxicity**: Elevated liver enzymes have been reported in some patients, though serious liver damage is rare and reversible upon discontinuation of the medication.

4. **Kidney Diseases**: While statins themselves are not directly linked to kidney disease, individuals with impaired renal function may require dosage adjustments due to the role of kidneys in metabolizing some statins.

5. **Cataracts**: Some studies suggest a possible association between statin use and an increased risk of cataracts, though more research is needed to establish causality.

6. **Hemorrhagic Strokes**: Statins reduce the risk of ischemic strokes but have been debated regarding their potential to increase hemorrhagic stroke risk. Overall, benefits in preventing strokes outweigh the risks.

7. **Psychiatric Complications**: Some patients report mood changes or cognitive issues, though it remains unclear if these are directly caused by statins or due to other factors.

In conclusion, while statins are generally safe and effective, their use should be tailored to individual patient needs with regular monitoring for side effects. Lifestyle factors such as diet and exercise also play a crucial role in managing cholesterol levels and overall health. Personalized medicine, considering the type of statin and individual variability in response, is essential for optimizing treatment outcomes.

Statins are commonly prescribed medications to lower cholesterol levels and reduce the risk of cardiovascular diseases. However, they can cause several adverse effects, including:

1. **Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus**: Statins may increase the risk of developing type 2 diabetes in some individuals.

2. **Muscular Symptoms**: Muscle pain, weakness, or cramps (myopathy) are common side effects. In rare cases, statins can lead to severe muscle damage (rhabdomyolysis).

3. **Liver Toxicity**: Statins may cause elevated liver enzymes, indicating potential liver damage in some patients.

4. **Kidney Diseases**: There is a reported association between statin use and kidney dysfunction or disease.

5. **Cataracts**: Some studies suggest an increased risk of cataract formation with long-term statin use.

6. **Hemorrhagic Strokes**: While statins reduce the overall risk of strokes, they may slightly increase the risk of hemorrhagic strokes in certain populations.

7. **Psychiatric Complications**: Rarely, statins have been linked to mood changes, memory loss, or other psychiatric issues.

It is important to weigh the benefits and risks of statin therapy with a healthcare provider, as these side effects are not universal and vary among individuals.

snippets.text: As a means to simplify and strengthen the support for this endeavor, we have developed oncoEnrichR, a flexible bioinformatics tool that allows cancer researchers to comprehensively interrogate a given gene list along multiple facets of cancer relevance. oncoEnrichR differs from general gene set analysis frameworks through the integration of an extensive set of prior knowledge specifically relevant for cancer, including ranked gene-tumor type associations, literature-supported proto-oncogene and tumor suppressor gene annotations, target druggability data, regulatory interactions, synthetic lethality predictions, as well as prognostic associations, gene aberrations and co-expression patterns across tumor types. The software produces a structured and user-friendly analysis report as its main output, where versions of all underlying data resources are explicitly logged, the latter being a critical component for reproducible science. We demonstrate the usefulness of oncoEnrichR through interrogation of two candidate lists from proteomic and CRISPR screens. oncoEnrichR is freely available as a web-based service hosted by the Galaxy platform (https://oncotools.elixir.no), and can also be accessed as a stand-alone R package (https://github.com/sigven/oncoEnrichR).

Treatments for endometrioma/endometriosis can be broadly categorized into hormonal therapies, surgical treatments, post-operative management, catheter-directed ethanol sclerotherapy, assisted reproductive technology (ART), and general management.

Hormonal therapies, such as progestin and GnRH therapies, are used post-surgery to improve menstrual bleeding profiles and reduce recurrence rates. These treatments can shrink the size of endometrioma but may carry a risk of ovarian cancer.

Surgical treatments include laparoscopic cystectomy and laser vaporization, which have shown positive outcomes in terms of mature follicles, fertilization rates, implantation rates, and clinical pregnancy rates. Postoperative medication significantly reduces recurrence rates.

Post-operative management with progesterone for 6 months is protective against recurrence, while clomiphene increases the risk.

Catheter-directed ethanol sclerotherapy (CDS) has minimal adverse effects on ovarian reserve.

Assisted reproductive technology (ART), including IVF and ICSI, is an option for infertility due to endometriosis. While women with endometriosis may have lower oocyte yields, their cumulative live-birth rates are similar to those of women without endometriosis.

Controlled ovarian stimulation protocols, such as GnRHa and GnRH antagonist protocols, are used for their suppression effect on ectopic endometrial tissue.

General management includes laparoscopy, expectant management, medical therapy, ovulation induction, and ART, but none offer a cure. There is a lack of data from randomized trials to determine the optimal management for pain relief, recurrence, and fertility.

ideal_answer: While there is a clear epidemiological association between hypothyroidism and depression, the causal relationship remains unclear.

The association between hypothyroidism and depression appears to be significant, with several potential mechanisms linking these conditions:

1. **Hormonal Imbalance**: Hypothyroidism involves low levels of thyroid hormones (T3 and T4), which are crucial for metabolism and brain function. This hormonal imbalance can lead to symptoms such as fatigue and weight gain, which may contribute to depressive feelings.

2. **Brain Function Impact**: Thyroid hormones play a role in regulating mood and cognitive functions. Reduced levels of these hormones might impair neurotransmitter production, including serotonin, affecting mood regulation and increasing the risk of depression.

3. **Inflammation Connection**: Both hypothyroidism and depression are associated with chronic inflammation, suggesting that inflammation could serve as a bridge between these conditions.

4. **Treatment Implications**: Addressing hypothyroidism through hormone replacement therapy may alleviate depressive symptoms, highlighting the importance of considering thyroid function in treating mood disorders.

5. **Demographic Factors**: Women are more prone to both conditions, and the severity of hypothyroidism might influence the strength of the association with depression.

In conclusion, while there is evidence supporting an increased risk of depression in individuals with hypothyroidism, further research is needed to fully understand the mechanisms and extent of this connection.

ideal_answer: Infectious myocarditis, also known as infectious myocardiopathy, is primarily caused by viral infections. The most common viral agents include Coxsackievirus B, adenovirus, parvovirus B19, and human herpesvirus 6. Other viruses such as influenza, cytomegalovirus, Epstein-Barr virus, and hepatitis C virus can also lead to myocarditis. In addition to viral causes, bacterial infections like those caused by Streptococcus, Staphylococcus, and Borrelia burgdorferi (the causative agent of Lyme disease) can result in myocarditis. Fungal infections, such as those caused by Candida and Aspergillus species, and parasitic infections, including Trypanosoma cruzi (Chagas disease) and Toxoplasma gondii, are less common but also recognized causes of infectious myocarditis.

Infectious myocarditis, also known as infectious myocardiopathy, can be caused by a variety of pathogens. The most common causes are viruses, including Coxsackievirus, Adenovirus, Parvovirus B19, Human herpesvirus 6 (HHV-6), Influenza virus, Hepatitis C virus, and Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV). Bacterial causes, though less common, include Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus species, Corynebacterium diphtheriae (causing diphtheria), Borrelia burgdorferi (causing Lyme disease), and Mycobacterium tuberculosis (causing tuberculosis). Fungal causes, which are rare, include Candida species, Aspergillus species, and Histoplasma capsulatum. Parasitic causes include Trypanosoma cruzi (causing Chagas disease) and Toxoplasma gondii (causing toxoplasmosis). Other infectious agents that can cause myocarditis include Rickettsia species (causing rickettsial diseases) and Mycoplasma pneumoniae. These pathogens lead to inflammation of the myocardium, and the exact pathogen responsible can often be identified through clinical evaluation, laboratory testing, and sometimes biopsy of the heart tissue.

Infectious myocarditis, a type of inflammatory heart disease, can be caused by a variety of infectious agents. The most common causes include viral infections such as those caused by Coxsackievirus, adenovirus, and parvovirus B19. Other viral causes include HIV, influenza, and the SARS-CoV-2 virus responsible for COVID-19. Bacterial infections, although less common, can also lead to myocarditis, with agents such as Borrelia burgdorferi (the cause of Lyme disease), Corynebacterium diphtheriae, and Mycobacterium tuberculosis being notable examples. Fungal infections, such as those caused by Candida species, and parasitic infections, such as those caused by Trypanosoma cruzi (Chagas disease) and Toxoplasma gondii, are also recognized causes of infectious myocarditis.

questions.body: What's the effect of germline-mediated immunoediting?

snippets.text: Germline-mediated immunoediting sculpts breast cancer subtypes and metastatic proclivity.

Tumors with the same diagnosis can have different molecular profiles and response to treatment. It remains unclear when and why these differences arise. Somatic genomic aberrations occur within the context of a highly variable germline genome. Interrogating 5870 breast cancer lesions, we demonstrated that germline-derived epitopes in recurrently amplified genes influence somatic evolution by mediating immunoediting. Individuals with a high germline-epitope burden in human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2/ERBB2) are less likely to develop HER2-positive breast cancer compared with other subtypes. The same holds true for recurrent amplicons defining three aggressive estrogen receptor (ER)-positive subgroups. Tumors that overcome such immune-mediated negative selection are more aggressive and demonstrate an "immune cold" phenotype. These data show that the germline genome plays a role in dictating somatic evolution.

Germline-mediated immunoediting refers to the process by which germline genetic variations influence the immune system's ability to recognize and eliminate cancer cells. Specifically, germline variants that alter the expression of certain proteins can create epitopes (molecular patterns) that are recognized by the immune system. This can lead to immunoediting, where the immune system selectively eliminates cancer cells expressing those epitopes. The studies suggest that germline-mediated immunoediting sculpts the molecular profiles and metastatic potential of breast cancers by selecting against amplification of genes containing high burdens of germline-derived epitopes.

Germline-mediated immunoediting modulates the immune response against breast cancer cells, reducing the likelihood of developing aggressive subtypes, such as HER2-positive breast cancer, in individuals with a high burden of germline-derived epitopes in relevant genes. This process selects against somatic gene amplification in these regions. However, tumors that overcome this editing tend to be more aggressive and exhibit an 'immune cold' phenotype. Understanding this process may lead to refined cancer risk stratification within breast cancer subtypes and the development of informative biomarkers, highlighting the germline genome's role in dictating cancer subtype and metastatic potential.

Germline-mediated immunoediting shapes tumor development by influencing somatic evolution through germline-derived epitopes, particularly in recurrently amplified genes. This process can refine risk stratification within breast cancer subtypes and serves as a potential biomarker for precision immunotherapy. Germline variations, such as HLA variations, have emerged as markers for predicting response to immune checkpoint inhibitors (ICIs). By modulating the antigenicity of neoantigens, immunoediting provides an evolutionary perspective on tumor immune evasion and treatment outcomes.

It affects the development of breast cancer subtypes by selecting against somatic gene amplification, leading to more aggressive and immune-evasive tumors. Additionally, it can create a pro-tumorigenic environment by disrupting the balance between protumor and antitumor immunity, and by selecting for immunologically evasive tumor variants, leading to more resistant cancer cell populations.

Elevated levels of pro-inflammatory cytokines like IL-1β, TNF-α, IL-6, and IL-8 have been observed, as well as increased oxidative stress markers like malondialdehyde and nitrotyrosine. In contrast, anti-inflammatory factors like TGF-β superfamily members were found to be decreased. This imbalance between pro- and anti-inflammatory signals may contribute to the pathophysiology of dysmenorrhea.

Inflammatory markers play a significant role in the pathophysiology of dysmenorrhea. Prostaglandins and leukotrienes are notably involved in generating dysmenorrhea symptoms, with increased menstrual prostaglandin release being a hallmark of primary dysmenorrhea. Elevated levels of these compounds during menstruation lead to intense uterine muscle contractions and cramps. The role of cytokines in primary dysmenorrhea is less understood, but some studies have shown up-regulation of pro-inflammatory cytokines such as IL-1A, IL-1B, CSF2, IL6, IL21, TNF, TNFRSF11B, IL5, and BMP3, and down-regulation of BMP4 and LEFTY2. However, another study found no significant differences in inflammatory markers like interleukin 6, tumor necrosis factor-alpha, and C-reactive protein between women with dysmenorrhea and those without. Oxidative stress is slightly aggravated in patients with dysmenorrhea, indicated by higher serum malondialdehyde levels. Clinical trials have shown that chlorella supplementation significantly decreased inflammatory markers such as PGE2, PGF2α, and high-sensitivity C-reactive protein in women with primary dysmenorrhea. Vitamin D and its metabolites may also reduce inflammatory cytokine levels, suggesting a potential therapeutic role. These findings highlight the complex interplay of inflammatory mediators in dysmenorrhea and suggest potential therapeutic targets for alleviating menstrual pain.

Inflammatory markers play a significant role in dysmenorrhea, particularly primary dysmenorrhea. Elevated levels of prostaglandins E2α (PGE2α) and F2α (PGF2α), as well as leukotrienes, are linked to intense uterine muscle contractions and menstrual cramps. The decrease in progesterone during the luteal phase leads to the secretion of arachidonic acid and its metabolites, causing inflammation and pain. The understanding of cytokines and other proinflammatory factors in primary dysmenorrhea is limited, though gene expression analysis has shown upregulation of pro-inflammatory cytokines and downregulation of anti-inflammatory cytokines in affected women. Studies found no significant difference in high-sensitivity C-reactive protein (hs-CRP) levels between women with and without primary dysmenorrhea. However, chlorella supplementation has been shown to significantly decrease inflammatory markers such as hs-CRP and prostaglandins in women with primary dysmenorrhea. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) like ibuprofen, diclofenac, and naproxen are effective first-line treatments due to their analgesic and anti-inflammatory effects. In summary, while prostaglandins and leukotrienes are well-established markers, the role of cytokines and other proinflammatory factors needs further research. NSAIDs and chlorella supplementation have shown efficacy in reducing inflammation and alleviating symptoms.

The Fontan procedure is a specialized heart surgery performed on individuals with single-ventricle congenital heart defects. This procedure is designed to improve circulation by separating systemic and pulmonary blood flows. Here's a concise breakdown:

1. **Location**: The surgery is performed on the heart, specifically modifying the atria (upper chambers of the heart).

2. **Purpose**: It alleviates the strain on the single ventricle by creating pathways that direct deoxygenated blood directly to the lungs and oxygenated blood to the body.

3. **Procedure Details**:
   - **Atrial Baffle/Septum**: A barrier is created within the atria to separate systemic venous return (deoxygenated blood) from pulmonary venous return (oxygenated blood).
   - **Venae Cavae to Pulmonary Arteries Connection**: Veins carrying deoxygenated blood are connected directly to the pulmonary arteries, bypassing the overburdened ventricle.

4. **Types**: Includes variations like the classic Fontan and Total Cavopulmonary Connection (TCPC), both aimed at enhancing blood flow efficiency.

In summary, the Fontan procedure is a heart surgery that restructures circulatory pathways to improve blood flow in patients with single-ventricle defects.

ideal_answer: Yes, toxic substances in air contribute to childhood asthma incidence and prevalence.

Yes, childhood asthma appears to be more common or severe in highly polluted areas. Studies consistently show a link between exposure to pollutants like PM10, NO2, SO2, and PM2.5 and increased incidence of asthma or worsening of respiratory symptoms in children. Comparative analyses across regions with varying pollution levels support this association, though the relationship's complexity is acknowledged. While the exact mechanisms are not fully understood, the evidence suggests a higher burden of childhood asthma in highly polluted areas.

Yes, childhood asthma is more common in highly polluted areas. Environmental pollution is identified as a critical risk factor for childhood asthma, and ubiquitous environmental exposures, including ambient air pollutants, are linked to the development and severity of the condition. Children living or attending schools near high traffic density roads are exposed to higher levels of motor vehicle air pollutants, increasing the incidence and prevalence of childhood asthma and wheeze. Studies have also identified a higher incidence of asthma among children in cities with high pollution levels compared to less polluted regions. Exposure to air pollutants is linked with poor asthma control and represents a modifiable risk factor for impaired lung function and increased asthma-related healthcare utilization.

Yes, childhood asthma is more common in highly polluted areas. Studies have shown that children living in areas with heavy air pollution are more likely to develop asthma compared to those in areas with no or light pollution. Exposure to traffic-related pollution, such as from roadways near homes and schools, increases the incidence and prevalence of childhood asthma and wheeze. Early-life exposure to ambient air pollution, including pollutants like NO2, PM2.5, CO, NO, PM10, SO2, and black carbon, is associated with an increased risk of asthma diagnosis. These findings suggest that air pollution, especially during early childhood, contributes to the development of asthma.

Based on the analysis of multiple studies, it is evident that childhood asthma is more prevalent in areas with high levels of air pollution. Key findings include:

1. **Air Pollutants as Risk Factors**: Studies consistently show that exposure to pollutants such as PM10 and NO2 increases the risk of childhood asthma. These pollutants are often associated with traffic and industrial emissions.

2. **Early-Life Exposure Impact**: Research indicates that exposure to mixed air pollutants during the first 1000 days of life significantly elevates the risk of developing asthma or wheezing in children.

3. **Contradictory Evidence on ER Visits**: While pollution contributes to asthma incidence, one study found no major link between air pollution and increased emergency room visits for asthma exacerbations.

4. **Uncertainty in Rural Areas**: There is some uncertainty regarding the effects of outdoor air pollution on childhood asthma in rural settings, suggesting that other factors might play a role in these environments.

5. **Contribution to Asthma Factors**: Outdoor air pollution accounts for 19% of asthma-related factors, with climatic and environmental elements contributing an additional 30%, highlighting the multifaceted nature of asthma causation.

In conclusion, the preponderance of evidence supports the notion that childhood asthma is more common in highly polluted areas due to the adverse effects of air pollutants on respiratory health.

Yes, childhood asthma appears to be more common in highly polluted areas, with multiple studies suggesting a positive association. Key pollutants linked to increased childhood asthma prevalence or severity include particulate matter (PM10) and nitrogen dioxide (NO2). While findings are consistent in regions like Central Europe, southwestern Ontario, and Northern Israel, some studies in Scandinavia found no overall pattern. The relationship is likely complex, influenced by various factors, but the majority of evidence supports a link between high pollution levels and increased childhood asthma.

The studies reviewed suggest that childhood asthma is more prevalent and severe in areas with higher levels of air pollution, particularly from traffic-related pollutants like particulate matter, nitrogen dioxide, and ozone. However, the relationship is complex, with other factors like genetics, socioeconomic status, and allergen exposure also playing important roles. Air pollution appears to exacerbate asthma symptoms and may contribute to the development of asthma, but is likely not the sole causative factor.

Yes, childhood asthma is more common in highly polluted areas. Studies have shown that exposure to poor air quality, traffic pollution, and industrial emissions is linked to a higher prevalence of asthma in children. Specifically, pollutants such as particulate matter (PM2.5), nitrogen dioxide (NO2), and sulfur dioxide have been associated with an increased risk of asthma. Additionally, social determinants of health, such as poverty and racism, can also contribute to higher rates of asthma in children. Overall, the evidence suggests that reducing exposure to air pollution and addressing social determinants of health can help mitigate the risk of childhood asthma.

The studies reviewed provide mixed evidence on whether childhood asthma is more common in highly polluted areas. Some studies found positive associations between air pollution levels and asthma incidence or severity in children, suggesting pollution may contribute to asthma development and exacerbations. However, other studies did not find a significant difference in asthma prevalence between areas with high versus low pollution levels. Overall, the evidence suggests air pollution likely exacerbates asthma symptoms in children with existing asthma, but the link between pollution and asthma incidence is less clear.

The RNA-binding protein RBFOX2 plays a key role in regulating cholesterol homeostasis in the liver by modulating alternative splicing of the Scarb1 gene, which encodes the scavenger receptor class B type I. RBFOX2 levels are decreased in diet-induced obesity, leading to dysregulation of Scarb1 splicing and altered lipid homeostasis in hepatocytes. Targeting this RBFOX2-mediated splicing network can alleviate obesity-induced inflammation and promote an anti-atherogenic lipoprotein profile.

Liver RBFOX2 plays a crucial role in maintaining cholesterol homeostasis through Scarb1 alternative splicing, which is disrupted in diet-induced obesity. It is essential for liver physiology, and its dysregulation contributes to lipotoxic effects. Notably, lower RBFOX2 expression is associated with hepatocellular carcinoma progression, suggesting a tumor-suppressive function. Additionally, RBFOX2 regulates insulin receptor splicing in hepatoma cells, influencing insulin signaling. Overall, RBFOX2's multifaceted effects are vital for liver function, cancer prevention, and metabolic regulation.
Liver RBFOX2 regulates cholesterol homeostasis by controlling Scarb1 alternative splicing and affecting lipid metabolism.

Downregulation of RBFOX2 also promotes pancreatic cancer progression and liver metastasis by regulating exon splicing events in transcripts encoding proteins involved in cytoskeletal remodeling programs.

Geographic atrophy (GA) is a form of advanced age-related macular degeneration (AMD) that affects the eyes and can lead to irreversible vision impairment and blindness. It does not involve the hand or foot.

This condition leads to irreversible visual decline due to progressive loss of retinal cells, ultimately impairing vision.

formation of ulcers and erosions within the mucous membranes. It is characterized by a wide range of clinical symptoms from serous-filled blisters located on the erythematous and oedematous substrate to asymptomatic infection.
Genital herpes (GH) is a sexually transmitted infection causing recurrent, self-limited genital, buttock, and thigh ulcerations.
Atypical genital herpes is often described in immunocompromised patients and can present as large, chronic, hyperkeratotic ulcers.

While it is well known that the characteristic presentation of HSV is a vesicular rash or crops of erosions, the clinical presentation of genital HSV infection in HIV is varied and can assume vegetative, hypertrophic, condyloma-like, nodular, ulcerative and tumour-like nodules or plaques.

ideal_answer: Genital herpes usually produces recurrent, self-limited genital (formation of ulcers and erosions within the mucous membranes), buttock, and thigh ulcerations which resolve over a period of 15 to 21 days

Genital herpes is a sexually transmitted infection caused by herpes simplex virus (HSV) types 1 and 2. Primary infections often present with severe symptoms like fever, malaise, painful genital ulcers, and tender lymph nodes that last 2-3 weeks. Recurrent infections tend to be milder with fewer lesions that heal faster. Atypical manifestations like chronic ulcers can occur in immunocompromised patients. Complications include aseptic meningitis, autonomic dysfunction, and secondary infections. Diagnosis is typically clinical but can be confirmed by viral culture or antigen detection. While antiviral drugs can reduce symptoms and viral shedding, there is no cure, and the psychological impact of a lifelong infection can be significant.

Manifestations of herpes genital infection include:

* Lesions and inflammation around the genital area
* Enlarged inguinal nodes
* Recurrent infections resulting in lesions
* Inflammation and pain in the genital area
* Potential for asymptomatic infection and transmission
* Recurrent nature of the infection
* Potential for complications such as eczema herpeticum, genital and gluteal recurrent herpes, and herpes zoster.

The infection can also manifest in other areas, such as the lumbar area or gluteus, and can be differentiated from varicella-zoster virus infection.

Additionally, the infection can cause:

* Psychological morbidity
* Physical consequences such as pain and discomfort
* Potential for neonatal infection if the mother is infected during pregnancy
* Potential for transmission to sexual partners
* Potential for complications such as encephalitis and genital forms of the disease.

Heterozygous loss of function in the SPTAN1 gene is associated with several conditions, including early childhood onset distal myopathy with chronic neurogenic features, hypoplastic brain structures, intellectual disability, and both fine and gross motor impairments. It also presents a broad phenotypical spectrum ranging from axonal neuropathy phenotypes to neurodevelopmental phenotypes with or without epilepsy. Additionally, it can cause early-onset epileptic encephalopathy, exerting a dominant-negative effect, and early infantile epileptic encephalopathy-5 (EIEE5), particularly when the variants occur de novo. These conditions highlight the critical role of SPTAN1 in neurological development and function.

Prion diseases are a rare group of fatal neurodegenerative disorders of humans and animals that manifest primarily as progressive dementia and ataxia. Unique to these diseases is the prion, a misfolded isoform of the prion protein that can transmit disease from cell to cell or host to host by associating with, and transforming, normal prion protein into the misfolded isoform (the pathogenic scrapie-inducing form).

The human transmissible spongiform encephalopathies (TSEs), or prion diseases, are a group of rapidly progressive disorders characterized by a spectrum of clinical abnormalities that include cognitive impairment, ataxia, myoclonus, and visual, pyramidal, and extrapyramidal signs. They share a spongiform (vacuolar) degeneration and variable amyloid plaque formation.

Being considered among the most fatal neurological conditions, Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease is a transmissible spongiform encephalopathy characterized by its unknown etiology and rapidly progressive neurodegenerative symptoms that often lead to a mean survival of 6 to 12 months. The accumulation of the prionic protein causes brain matter degeneration, which leads to a set of clinical findings that include rapidly progressive dementia, myoclonus, tremors, cerebellar ataxia, and extrapyramidal signs.

ideal_answer: Prion diseases manifest primarily with CNS symptoms such as progressive dementia, pyramidal and extrapyramidal signs, language and writing impairments, ataxia, myoclonus, epilepsia, movement disorders, bulbar signs, communication impairment, symptoms from the peripheral nervous system, and psychiatric and visual symptoms.

Prion diseases are a group of rare, progressive neurodegenerative disorders characterized by distinctive clinical features and neuropathological findings. Key characteristics include: 1. Neurological Symptoms : Evolving dementia with symptoms such as ataxia (loss of coordination), myoclonus (involuntary muscle jerks), pyramidal signs (e.g., increased reflexes, spasticity), and extrapyramidal signs (e.g., rigidity, bradykinesia). 2. Cognitive and Psychiatric Symptoms : Isolated anomic aphasia (difficulty finding words) and other language impairments; psychiatric symptoms such as anxiety or depression may also occur. 3. Visual and Otologic Symptoms : Isolated visual disturbances and otologic symptoms (e.g., hearing loss, vertigo). 4. Seizures and Epileptic Events : Non convulsive status epilepticus and epileptic seizures are common presentations. 5. Movement Disorders : Peripheral nervous system involvement, bulbar signs (e.g., difficulty swallowing, speaking), and other movement disorders may be observed. 6. Encephalopathies : Widespread brain dysfunction leading to cognitive decline and neuropsychiatric symptoms. 7. Pathological Features : Neuronal loss, astrogliosis (reactive astrocytes), and spongiform changes in the brain tissue. These diseases often present as acute or subacute neurological conditions and are associated with a rapid progression of symptoms leading to severe disability and death.

Mechanisms of tissue-specific gene expression regulation via 3D genome organization are poorly understood. Here we uncover the regulatory chromatin network of developing T cells and identify SATB1, a tissue-specific genome organizer, enriched at the anchors of promoter-enhancer loops. We have generated a T-cell specific Satb1 conditional knockout mouse which allows us to infer the molecular mechanisms responsible for the deregulation of its immune system. H3K27ac HiChIP and Hi-C experiments indicate that SATB1-dependent promoter-enhancer loops regulate expression of master regulator genes (such as Bcl6), the T cell receptor locus and adhesion molecule genes, collectively being critical for cell lineage specification and immune system homeostasis.

Neoantigens are novel peptide sequences that arise from mutations in the tumor cell's DNA, which lead to changes in the amino acid sequence of expressed proteins. These proteins are then processed into peptides, which are presented on the cancer cell surface via Human Leukocyte Antigen (HLA) molecules. This presentation triggers a tumor-specific T cell response. ideal_answer: Sudden deafness, also known as sudden sensorineural hearing loss (SSNHL), can be attributed to various causes, including viral infections, vascular factors, idiopathic causes, inflammatory processes, acoustic trauma, and other miscellaneous causes. Viral infections are implicated in about one-third of SSNHL cases, while vascular issues account for approximately 50%. Idiopathic SSNHL, where the cause remains unknown, is the most common category. Inflammatory processes, such as elevated levels of complement components and inflammatory cytokines, also play a role. Acoustic trauma is a significant cause, particularly in men, accounting for about 10% of cases. Other causes include psychogenic disorders, disseminated encephalitis, syphilitic labyrinthitis, Cogan's syndrome, meningitis, acoustic neuroma, rupture of the round window membrane, epidemic parotitis, and tumors of the cerebellopontine angle. Genetic factors, such as mutations in genes like GJB2, MTHFR, ApoE, and interleukin-1 gene polymorphisms, have been associated with SSNHL. Metabolic and systemic conditions, including type 2 diabetes, Ménière disease, and vestibular schwannoma, are also linked to sudden hearing loss. Comprehensive diagnostic evaluation is essential to identify the underlying cause and guide appropriate treatment.

Sudden deafness, known as sudden sensorineural hearing loss (SSHL), often has idiopathic causes, meaning the cause is unknown. However, several known factors contribute to its development. These include vascular issues such as cochlear ischemia or infarction, particularly from occlusion of the vestibulo cochlear artery (VCA). Autoimmune diseases and infections are also implicated, alongside functional, metabolic, and neurological disorders. Traumatic events, exposure to toxins, and other vascular problems can also lead to sudden deafness. There is a noted hereditary component in some Chinese populations, though its genetic mechanisms are complex. Viral infections, vascular insufficiency, autoimmune disorders, and stress are primary contributors, while secondary causes include tumors, strokes, and radiation.

The causes of sudden deafness, also known as sudden sensorineural hearing loss (SSNHL), are often multifactorial and can be broadly categorized into primary and secondary causes. Primary causes include viral infections (e.g., herpes simplex virus or varicella zoster virus), vascular insufficiency (e.g., cochlear ischemia due to occlusion of the vestibulo cochlear artery), autoimmune disorders, and stress related factors. Secondary causes are those that arise as a result of other underlying conditions, such as neoplasms affecting the auditory pathway, strokes causing brainstem or cerebellar injuries, or irradiation exposure. Other contributing factors include infections (e.g., meningitis, labyrinthitis), metabolic disorders, traumatic injury to the ear, and toxic exposure to ototoxic chemicals or medications. Additionally, SSNHL has been associated with hereditary factors in certain populations, though its genetic mechanisms are complex and not fully understood.

Sudden deafness can result from a variety of factors. Commonly, both viral infections and vascular issues are implicated, with evidence pointing to microvascular events, thrombosis, embolism, or vasospasm leading to impaired cochlear perfusion. Immune-mediated damage is another suggested cause, involving either autoimmune processes or inflammation secondary to infection. Inner ear bleeding, such as labyrinthine hemorrhage, has also been recognized, particularly once diagnostic imaging became available. Other potential causes include infections like Mycoplasma pneumoniae and even retroviral involvement. In some cases, exposure to certain toxins, medications, or underlying conditions such as chronic leukemia may trigger sudden sensorineural hearing loss. Despite these identified mechanisms, many cases remain idiopathic, where no clear etiology can be determined.

The etiology of sudden deafness is varied and often remains undetermined. While in many cases no apparent cause is identified, potential factors include viral infections, vascular events such as cochlear ischemia or occlusion of the vestibulo-cochlear artery, autoimmune disorders, and inner ear issues like cochlear membrane rupture. Other suggested causes encompass metabolic diseases, traumatic events, toxins, neurological disorders, and even stress. Some research indicates a possible hereditary component in certain populations. It's important to note that sudden hearing loss can be a symptom of underlying conditions affecting the inner ear or the entire body.

Sudden deafness can arise from multiple causes, with many cases remaining idiopathic (unknown cause), while identified causes include vascular issues like cochlear ischemia and vestibulo-cochlear artery occlusion, viral infections, autoimmune disorders, and stress. Secondary causes encompass neoplasms, stroke, metabolic disorders, trauma, toxin exposure, and neurological conditions, with some evidence suggesting genetic factors may play a role in certain populations.

questions.body: Describe the SEQUOIA tool for predicting cancer transcriptomics profiles from histology images

snippets.text: Here, we develop SEQUOIA, a transformer model to predict cancer transcriptomes from whole-slide histology images. To enable the full potential of transformers, we first pre-train the model using data from 1,802 normal tissues. Then, we fine-tune and evaluate the model in 4,331 tumor samples across nine cancer types. The prediction performance is assessed at individual gene levels and pathway levels through Pearson correlation analysis and root mean square error.

Then, it's fine-tuned and evaluated in 4,331 tumor samples across nine cancer types. SEQUOIA is a linearized transformer model that predicts cancer transcriptomic profiles from WSIs. SEQUOIA is developed using 7584 tumor samples across 16 cancer types, with its generalization capacity validated on two independent cohorts comprising 1368 tumors. Accurately predicted genes are associated with key cancer processes, including inflammatory response, cell cycles and metabolism. Further, SEQUOIA is demonstrated in stratifying the risk of breast cancer recurrence and in resolving spatial gene expression at loco-regional levels. SEQUOIA hence deciphers clinically relevant information from WSIs, opening avenues for personalized cancer management.

CD47 is an integrin-associated penta-transmembrane protein that possesses an immunoglobulin-like domain in its extracellular region. We have now investigated the role of CD47 in the regulation of epithelial cell spreading and migration. CD47 is colocalized with E-cadherin at cell-cell adhesion sites of epithelial cells. A Ca2+ switch experiment showed that CD47 was endocytosed and then relocalized to cell-cell adhesion sites in a similar manner to E-cadherin. Such polarized localization of CD47 required the multiple spanning region of this protein. Forced expression of CD47 induced cell spreading with marked lamellipodium formation and resulted in both partial disruption of cell-cell adhesion and enhancement of the hepatocyte growth factor-stimulated scattering of Madin-Darby canine kidney cells. The CD47-induced cell spreading was blocked by inhibition of Src and mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase. Thus, these results suggest that CD47 participates in the regulation of cell-cell adhesion and cell migration through reorganization of the actin cytoskeleton in epithelial cells. This function of CD47 is mediated by the activation of Src and mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase.

CD47 is a ubiquitous 50 kDa five-spanning membrane receptor that belongs to the immunoglobulin superfamily. This receptor, also known as integrin-associated protein, mediates cell-to-cell communication by ligation to transmembrane signal-regulatory proteins SIRPα and SIRPγ and interacts with integrins. CD47 is also implicated in cell-extracellular matrix interactions via ligation with thrombospondins. Furthermore, CD47 is involved in many and diverse cellular processes, including apoptosis, proliferation, adhesion and migration. It also plays a key role in many immune and cardiovascular responses.

CD47, also known as integrin-associated protein (IAP), is a transmembrane protein with multiple biological functions including regulation of efferocytosis and leukocyte trafficking. It regulates cell adhesiveness, migration and activation and platelet aggregation through binding to thrombospondins. CD47 is the extracellular ligand for human signal-regulatory proteins, thus it causes negative regulatory effect. CD47 induces costimulatory signals on activation of T cell, T cell apoptosis and T cell anergy and enhances the efficiency of TCR signaling. CD47 can also function as a marker of self on erythrocytes, and likely also on other cells, by binding to the inhibitory receptor SIRPalpha, preventing phagocytosis.

CD47 functions to regulate integrin-mediated responses, such as cell adhesion, migration, and activation, and it also serves as a 'don't eat me' signal to prevent phagocytosis by macrophages through its interaction with SIRPα, which is crucial for immune evasion by tumor cells.

CD47, also known as the Cluster of Differentiation 47 or integrin-associated protein, is a ubiquitously expressed cell surface receptor that plays a critical role in maintaining immune system homeostasis. It functions as a "don't-eat-me" signal by engaging with signal regulatory protein alpha (SIRPα) on phagocytic cells, such as macrophages, to inhibit host cell phagocytosis. This interaction prevents the immune system from mistakenly destroying healthy cells. In the context of cancer, CD47's role in suppressing innate immune signaling has made it a target for immunotherapy, as cancer cells can exploit this pathway to evade phagocytosis and immune surveillance.
CD47 functions as a self-recognition molecule that inhibits phagocytosis and regulates immune signaling.

This interaction inhibits phagocytosis, allowing cells to evade immune clearance, and plays a broader role in self-recognition and immune homeostasis.
